lines.text: You little tramp, you!

Yeah, I'm a tramp, and who's to blame? My Father. A swell start you gave me. Ever since I was fourteen, what's it been? Nothing but men! Dirty rotten men! And you're lower than any of them. I'll hate you as long as I live!
He's a big politician, ain't he?
He's a big sumpthin'... and it ain't a politician!
Ha-ha-ha! Honey, you makes me tickle.

[Lily seen putting on lipstick after her boss is reprimanded and fired for having followed her into the Ladies Rest Room]
Young woman! We have no place here for a girl of your sort. You're through, tonight.

Why, Mr. Stevens, it wasn't my fault. He followed me in there. What could I do? He's my boss and I have to earn my living. Oh, I'm so ashamed. It's the first time anything like that has ever happened to me.
[Starts to cry]
Well, I'll think it over. Report tomorrow as usual.

I can't do it. I have to think of myself. I've gone through a lot to get those things. My life has been bitter and hard. I'm not like other women. All the gentleness and kindness in me has been killed. All I've got are those things. Without them, I'd be nothing.

[Ed walks into Lily's bedroom]
You haul your freight outta here.
What's a matter? You gettin' particular?
Maybe I am. Did you ever take a good look at yourself?
Yeah, you're exclusive, *you* are! The sweetheart of the night shift. Come on, you're wastin' my time. Everybody knows about you.
Yeah, well you ain't going to!
Did somebody in your home play the piano?
Anybody that had a nickel.
Say, I like it here. How 'bout a job? Oh, now don't tell me in this great, big building there ain't some place for me?
Have you had any experience?
Plenty.
[Rolls eyes]
I'd rather wait in there. I hate crowds. Don't you?
The boss won't be back for an hour.
Well then why don't we go in and talk this over?
Of course, if Fuzzy Wuzzy really wants to give me something, he could put a few more pennies in my bank account.
My Dear, ask me something difficult.
Oh, not here. Somebody might...
There's only one thing I want.
Name it, and it's yours.
I'd like to have a "Mrs." on my tombstone.

[Chico accidently drops some glasses on the floor]
Now, look what you went and done. You're fired! You lazy, thievin', little son-of-a...
Hey! Easy with the whip.
You keep outta this!
[to Chico]
Go on, get outta my house!
If Chico goes, I go.
What?
You heard me.
Don't you talk to me that way. I'm your father!
That's my tough luck.
Come here, sweetheart.
Oh, lay off, you big ape!
How long are you going to stand it? Why don't you get out, before its too late?
Where would I go?
Out into the world. You could make something of yourself. You have Power!

[Disbelievingly]
Yeah, I'm a ball of fire, I am.
You don't realize your potentialities.
Come again?
Did you read dat book I gave you?
Oh, I tried to, but I didn't understand it very good.
It's by Nietzsche! The greatest philosopher of all time!
Well, I never did get much good out of books.
You are a fool. You could learn a lot from dat book. But, if you are content to stay here like a dumb animal, in this miserable life, then I wash my hands from you.
Say, what do you think we're running here?
It looks to me like a zoo!
So, now what?

[Sarcastically]
Well, the future looks very bright. Just as I was leaving the cemetery, Ed Sipple made me a proposition. And last night the manager at the... burlesque house offered me a job in the chorus to do a strip act.
A strip act?
Yeah, show my shape.
Well, that's a business in its self.
Oh, I guess I ain't much of a business woman.
What's going to become of you? Its up to you to decide. If you stay in this town, you are lost.
Where would I go? Paris? I got four bucks.
You're a coward. I mean it! You let life defeat you. You don't fight back.
What chance has a woman got?

More chance than man. A woman, young, beautiful, like you, can get anything she wants in the world. Because you have Power over men! But you must use men! Not let them use you. You must be a master! Not a slave. Look, here, Nietzsche says, "All life, no matter how we idealize it, is nothing more nor less than exploitation." That's what I'm telling you! Exploit yourself! Go to some big city where you will find opportunities. Use men! Be strong! Defiant! Use men! To get the t'ings you want.

[contemplative pause]
Yeah.
[puffs a cigarette]
Is that a permanent?
Yeah. They do it for 3.35 at Bourne's Beauty Shop.
Where's that at?
81st and Broadway.
Oh, hello Jimmy.
Listen, Baby face, how 'bout havin' dinner tonight? I've got two tickets for Vanities.
You don't know you're out, till they stop counting. Wake up, kid! Baby face is moving out of your class.

[Answers phone]
Mr. Stevens office. No, he ain't, I mean isn't.
Have a drink?
No thanks. I never touch it.
Oh, you don't want me to drink alone?
Well, maybe just a sip.
[Pours herself a slug of whiskey and downs it in one gulp]

[Lily sashays into Mr. Stevens' office]
Haven't I told you never to come beyond the front of this desk.
Oh, but I get so lonesome out there all by myself.
[Runs her hands through Mr. Stevens' hair]
Don't do that! How do you expect me to get any work done.
Hold me close.
[They embrace as Mr. Stevens' fiancée walks in. Mr. Stevens chases after her. Lily lights up a cigarette]
Will you tell me where you live?
My telephone number is Skylight 3-3215.
Ohhhhh! Is these the new furs, honey?
Not so much honey.
Yes, ma'am.
Does my baby want brandy?
Anything you say.
[Lily pours some into a snifter and hands it to Mr. Carter]
Won't you have some?
Oh, no! I never drink.
Isn't this cozy. You know, sometimes your little girl gets awful lonesome here, all by herself.
I wish you'd get rid of that fantastic colored girl.

[Sternly]
No. Chico stays.
Alight. Alright. Alright.
What's this?
Oh, that? It come while you was out. Its some books from old Mr. Cragg, back in Erie.
You run along and have a good time.
I sliced some turkey for you. Its in the ice box.
Face life as you find it - defiantly and unafraid. Waste no energy yearning for the moon. Crush out all sentiment.
Wait a minute, you're kinda mixed up, aren't you? I thought you left town?
Well, what else could I do? I was in a...
Jam? Well, I won't let you get in another. See what I mean?
Lily, don't do this to me. I can't stand it. Its been brutal not seeing you.
Yeah? Well, you better get used to it. Listen, I don't owe you a thing. Whatever I do is my own business. You never had but one idea about me. That's all I ever meant to you.
Oh, but, Lily...
You made your choice. Now, what do you want?
You mean - I can't - see you anymore?

[Sarcastically]
How did you guess it?
Its the sweetest New Year's present I ever got.
Sit down. I like to look at you.

[Sarcastically]
So, you want to marry me, huh? Isn't that beautiful. Get outta here, or I'll...

With a scandal on top of us and a blast of dangerous notoriety that has shaken the people's confidence in our bank, what do you do? You demand the President's resignation and break your necks to elect a new President. A playboy! Who hasn't had a day's banking experience in his life. How do you expect a society-globetrotter to restore confidence?
Perhaps you've forgotten that his grandfather founded this bank.

[Meeting with the Board of Directors]
Gentlemen, I shan't take up your time telling you how much I appreciate this honor. Some of you probably think I should stick to polo and not try to run a bank. But, I'm sure that with your help, I can't go very far wrong.

I'm desperate. I know what the world thinks. Everyone blames me! No one knows the truth. I was all alone here, no family, no friends. I was working hard, earning my own living. And, then - and then Baby came.
Baby?
That's what I always called Mr. Carter. I was a victim of circumstance.
All I want is a chance to earn an honest living.

Miss Powers, no one could help but be moved by your story. It's obvious, as you say, that you were a victim of circumstance. You have our sympathy. Of course, any talk of money must be very distressing to a sensitive person. You've told us how distasteful it would be for you to accept money from a paper. I'm afraid it would be equally distasteful to accept money from the bank. Perhaps we've been somewhat crude in our suggestion. You also told us how hard you had to work. When this thing happened, were you - working very hard?
Yeah, but not at the bank.
Thank you, Miss Powers. You'll like Paris. It's delightful in the Springtime.
Yeah, you think of everything, don't ya?
Of course, if I go to Berlin, the food there is very fattening.
Well, you could go to Karlsbad afterward and reduce?
The very thing! Could you arrange it for me?
Frankly, I am surprised.
Why?
I didn't expect you to stick to the job.
That's why I stuck.
It would have been easy for you, to come here to Paris and have a somewhat - gayer time.
It would have been too easy.
This is as far as I go.
Oh, so this is where you live.
All the charm of the old world and the old world plumbing.
Would you take Harry with you.

[to Harry]
Come along, you loathsome little man.

[Referring to Lily]
Courtland always finds the most devastating girl!
Well, if you get bored with Courtland, you come along and join us later.
Oh, that would be jolly!
Are you really thinking? Or, just pretending to?
That's the nice part of being with a mastermind. You do the thinking for both of us.
Then you're coming to Deauville?
Deauville's too crowded.
How about Biarritz?
Not crowded enough.
I'll tell you what, would you like to motor through the chateau country?
And see all those lovely fourteenth century ceilings?
[Shakes her head no]
You're hard to please.
No, I'm not really. Just a little disappointed.
Disappointed? In what?
You.
Why?
Oh, I don't know. I was hoping you wouldn't be like everybody else. Silly of me, wasn't it?
Well, I'm disappointed in myself. Because you're beginning to upset me.
Darling, how long is this going on?
Aren't you happy?
These have been the three happiest days of my life. But...
But, what?
Well, I don't enjoy saying good night to you, every night, outside the door of your stateroom.
Don't you realize I'm in love with you?
No you're not.

Yes, I am! I can't wait to get back to Paris to buy all the jewels and Cartiers. To take you to the motor salons - where you can pick out any car that you like. I want to give you a house in Paris and another in New York. There isn't anything in the world I wouldn't give you.
That isn't love.
Will you stop blaming Trenholm! It isn't his fault.
When a bank closes because of mismanagement, who is to blame?
All of us are to blame! You can't hold one person responsible.
Rot! You'll see who's held responsible.
Bring me that pigskin case on the bed. You know what's in this bag?
No.
Half a million dollars. Someday I'll have the other half that goes with it.
You sure will! You can get anything you put your mind on.
That's all there is to it. If you fire me, we're through. It isn't the job, I don't mind that. But, it just goes to show me how much you care.
Well, you know how much I...
How much you what?
[Moves in close]
Are you letting me go?
[Kiss]
